bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Henry Hanson , March 11, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] informs Hanson that he has been lecturing on malaria and yellow fever at Johns Hopkins. Currently he is working on a brief history of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Henry Hanson, March 11, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Hanson
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
March 11, 1922.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p:
I am dictating this to my daughter because I am on my back again.
I will tell you the cause of it presently.

I have received tow letters from you--indeed three--Jan. 19th.:
Jan. 20th. and Feb. 20th.--since I wrote you. The reason of my not do-
ing so earlier is (1) I have not been entirely well--my “kink” has given
me a good deal of trouble.

More efficient as a cause of silence, however, has been the fact
that I have been giving a few lectures on the sanitary management of
malaria and yellow fever at the Hopkins School of Hygiene and have, in-
deed, two more to give: Only one--the lastoone--will be on yellow fever.
This is rather a cavalier way to treat a somewhat extensive subject.
Naturally, I won't be able to go into details, but will exploit your
fish campaign as being not only le dernier cri in Stegomyia control, but
the most efficient method therefor.

There are quite a number of Latin Americans in the class and I at
least wish to remove the erroneous ideas they have imbibed from the Pas-
teur Commissions at Rio and Martinique. It is strange how uncritical a
Latin American is in accepting as authoritative a statement from another
Latin. Even Colonel Verne, who is not a Latin American, claims that Beau-
perthuy picked out the Stegomyia as a vector of yellow fever. The “Culex
bobo” of Beauperthuy, I feel quite sure, included Culex sollicitans, al-
though he may have confounded Stegomyia with it. He makes it a distinctly
marine species of “brackish marshes.”

The cause of my present collapse is quite certainly from having rid-
den back from Baltimore, from one of those lectures, in a jolting trolley.
The “kink” cannot stand steady continued vibration.
vibration.

In addition, I have finally agreed to write a brief history of yellow
fever for the I. H. B., and have, indeed, been at work on it--getting data
and taking notes--since about January 10th. Hence my knowledge of Beau-
perthuy!

I declined at first to write it, but offered to work on it for six
weeks or two months until I could determine:1/. Whether I could do the work
to my own satisfaction--I lay more stress on my own criticism than on
that of the I. H. B.--2/ Whether it would be right to stop my abstracts
and reviews of the malaria articles in journals (all except Italian, which
I can't read). These, since October, I have been getting out mimeographed
and sending to the men in the field, and, indeed to a considerable num-
ber of other people interested in malaria. 3/ How much of an onus the
work would be.

I have finally decided--as I said--to take it up. I will have to
drop the malaria work--for which I am really sorry. Sent off the last
little article (a review of some work done in Batavia by the Dutch) last
evening. It is quite an onus, but I believe I can do it, and I presume
it ought to be done; though it is not really construtive work, like that
I have been doing in malaria--more in the nature of an ornament, I think.
However, I have decided.

I was exceedingly glad to get the pictures of the “kids.” Martha
is a charming little thing. Virgil I would not have known. He is a fine
looking, great big boy--as ernest as he was when a baby! I thought he
was going to develope a considerable streak of self-will: would want what
he wanted and want it now! Has he ever admitted the fact of gravitation?
or will he still undertake to jump from one person's arms to another's
clear across the room? A baby reminds me much of Einstein in his reject-
ion of Isaac Newton's laws.

I am inclined to think that with your small force it was probably
probably
3.
wise not to take Dunn off the actual inspection and put him on the scien-
tific side of Stegomyia work. Most--not all--of the problems you enumer-
ate have been either settled or quite well studied.

One addition you have made to our knowledge of their breeding places.
Francis states that larvae have not been found in puddles with earth bot-
toms: Yours is with earth sides and this last, from our Peruvian exper-
ience, is correct and naturally would be so from a consideration of the
way she deposits her eggs at the very edge of the water--or even on the
side itself. She has no knowledge of the bottom in--say-- a 4 ft. botija,
while the side is a matter of importance to her in laying.

The recent work of Gordon and Young has settled beyond any cavil
the fact that Stegomyia over 14 days old, and having received at least
two previous blood meals, feed more often in the day (double as often)
than in the night. Their work was scarcely necessary, as that of Seidelin
in Merida and Goeldi in Para, as well, I think, as my own observations on
conveyance in Panama, was sufficient.

This is the 11th. of March--the day you left us at Salaverry last
year. I judge you feel very differently from what you did then. We knew
your work was cut out out for you and was going to be a long, hard job--
and our prognosis was about right! We both considered it more than probable
that yellow fever was in Libertad at that time. I judge that we were
right in that too. If it had not come in of itself it was practically
compelled to do so by the maritime quarantine imposed--January 12th. or
14th., I believe--by the Salubridad.

About Mexico and Central America--I don't think the work has been
handled quite as well as it might have been--although no one knows better
than we do the impossibility of judging from a distance of the difficul-
ties that the man actually in charge of the work may have. I think they
have done too much following up of small local oputbreaks. My advice to
Lyster when I saw him, and since then to White, was to concentrate and
nd
4.
practically confine their work (Stegomyia work) to “key-points”--large
towns or places which, from their travel-relations, would spread infection
to large towns. To take such places, whether they were infected now or
not, and render them uninfectable and not to worry about little out-
breaks--at least not for their own sakes: That small places would free
their own selves if you gave them a little time.

I am not ill pleased to see that the fever has--or rather has had--
a wide distribution in Mexico. It means that many small places have burn-
ed out and I cannot but hope that a campaign pressed will finish it by
next winter. It would be a good thing, however, if White had two or three
more good American Sub-Directors. I think he took two down with him: One
(Scannell) should be a good man.

Whether the Guatamala revolution will make a back-fire or not I do
not know. I think not.

I believe your work is done. It is right--it was necessary as an
insurance--to keep on to, or into, June. but One would think that if any
yellow fever were kept over it would have shown up by this time, although
it is fairly hot--in the north at any rate--up to May 1st. With Peru goes
the West Coast of South America and the freeing of that unit from yellow
fever is a very great thing--important not only on account of the large
area freed, but (unless the Cosmos Line starts up again) on account of
this freedom being permanent --an important stepping stone to the perma-
nent elimination of yellow fever.

With very best remembrances to you all, in which Laura asks to be
included,
